KB)</span></a></div></div></div></div> <p><strong>Banks have long pondered</strong> the untapped value of the commercial segment but
often lack the means to identify the precise needs of individual companies in
this large and diverse population. This is changing, however. By mining huge
reserves of customer data, banking analytics leaders are meeting the needs of
hundreds of thousands of commercial customersfrom small businesses to
medium-size corporationswith new levels of convenience and cost efficiency.
Several banks have achieved a ten-fold increase in the success rate of product
recommendations, thus delivering highly relevant offers with clear economic
benefit. This article highlights recent examples of how next-product-to-buy
(NPtB) recommendation engines are identifying time-critical needs for their
small- and medium-size enterprise (SME) and mid-corporate clients.</p>
<h2>The problem: Most businesses are invisible</h2>
<p>Many banks currently use rules-based models
to generate recommendations for SMEs and
mid-corporate companies (with annual sales
up to $100 million), but with limited success.
Relationship managers often view these recommendations
with skepticism, as conversion
rates typically range between three and
five percent. They resort to general propositions
designed for the consumer segment and
devote most of their energy to those clients
whose businesses they already know well and
whose needs they can anticipate reliably. The
result is that 25 percent of a banks commercial
customers usually account for 85 percent
of the revenues, and the remaining 75 percent
represents the long tail of untapped potential.
These companies are effectively invisible
to the banks sales force (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/using%20data%20to%20unlock%20the%20potential%20of%20an%20sme%20and%20midcorporate%20franchise/svgz-using-data-unlock-potential-sme-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Cross-selling efforts often focus on the companies that relationship managers know well." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/using%20data%20to%20unlock%20the%20potential%20of%20an%20sme%20and%20midcorporate%20franchise/svgz-using-data-unlock-potential-sme-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>The solution: Anticipate the clients next step</h2>
<p>Banks are investing in building up predictive
models globally: US Bank and TD Bank
in North America; Itau and Banco do Brasil
in Latin America; Barclays Bank and Lloyds
Bank in the UK; ING, Banco Santander, and
BBVA in Europe are just some examples of
banks improving their commercial performance
by <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/how-machine-learning-can-improve-pricing-performance">leveraging machine learning</a>. These
advanced techniques have proven effective
in diverse customer segments, from self-employed
individuals to large corporate customers.
SMEs and mid-corps are the sweet-spot
for NPtB, as they generate massive amounts
of data, which are typically underused. With
the help of advanced analytics decisioning
engines, banks have demonstrated that it is
now practical to mine vast (and often messy)
amounts of data, separating signal from
noise, to arrive at precise recommendations
for a clients next action. In addition, by
broadening the types of data collected for the
commercial segment, banks are also analyzing
customer behaviors, transactions, and
customer preferences across more extensive
databases.</p>
<p>Successful implementation of NPtB engines
has boosted new sales upwards of 30 percent
and increased commercial segment revenues
by between two to three percent. The impact
on sales efficiency has been radical in some cases, with an increase of more than 50 percent
in the number of leads offered per client and as
many as six out of ten customers purchasing a
new product in response to a sales call.</p>
<h2>Leveraging data for NPTB recommendations</h2>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>From NBA to NPtB</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Next-product-to-buy (NPtB) models represent a significant advance over those using first- and second-generation
next-best-action (NBA) methodologies. In the past decade, product recommendations for corporate transaction
banking were generated through statistical analysis of historically observed behaviors across diverse sub-segments
(usually between 10 and 20 in number). Each recommendation called attention to a particular area (e.g., disbursement
services, accounts receivable and working capital management, investments, trade finance, foreign exchange)
and targeted broadly companies sharing general characteristics, as defined by a limited range of profile data, for example,
company size, geography, industry, supply chain position, financial behaviors.</p>
<p>With the proliferation of data points, second-generation NBA recommendation engines required more intensive work
to describe the data, that is, to teach machines the data features to look for when analyzing a data set. This enabled
banks to identify specific products (e.g., receivables financing, FX hedging, corporate procurement cards) that a customer
would likely be considering. However, the analysis behind these recommendations focused on behaviors within
specific cash-management functions, reinforcing the narrow scope of product silos, with little opportunity to optimize
financial performance across the full value chain.</p>
<p>The goal of feature engineering, therefore, is to find the best combination of variables to enable a learning algorithm
to recognize meaningful patterns in a particular data set. It is a key process in developing a conventional NBA model
and until recently was a time-consuming manual process drawing on deep knowledge of business practices.</p>
<p>Drawing upon a much broader set of structured and unstructured data and taking advantage of recent gains in processing
capacity, todays NPtB engines generate recommendations that are much more granular and precise than
is possible with NBA models. The improvement in analytical sophistication and processing power comes thanks to
deep learning, which can develop highly accurate predictive algorithms. Neural networks make it possible to automate
the discovery of data features and the identification of the best combination of features to produce the targeted
prediction. These calculations produce remarkably precise predictions and deliver actionable results.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>More than a decade ago, Amazon and Netflix
began leveraging data and analytics to
improve their cross-selling efforts. They
started with simple analytics, dividing huge
customer populations into several dozens of
microsegments according to key behaviors
(inputs). In order to achieve this new level of
precision, they used singular value decomposition
(SVD) to classify customers according
to patterns in their purchase histories, each
pattern culminating in a target output, that
is, the <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/how-to-make-sure-your-next-product-or-service-launch-drives-growth">next product to buy</a>. The number of
inputs and the complexity of the algorithms
used to analyze these inputs have been increasing
in recent years, achieving outputs
that have much greater precision than was
possible with next-best-action (NBA) models.
(See sidebar From NBA to NPtB for a summary of the
evolution of NPtB from NBA.)</p>
<p>The NBA engines employed by Amazon (with
more than 300 million customers reported
in 2016) and Netflix (125 million subscribers
reported in the first quarter of 2018) are not entirely suited to banks serving SMEs and
large corporations with products/services
that address a relatively narrow range of
business activitydomestic and cross-border
payments, financing, documentary credit,
investments, and insurance. By building NBA
recommendation engines designed specifically
for transaction banking, banks have
increased service levels and profitability,
improving their responsiveness to SMEs and
helping large corporate clients cut through
complex banking relationships and account
structures to optimize liquidity.</p>
<p>To maximize the impact of each recommendation,
decision engines should identify both
customer needs and the preferred channel(s)
for delivering the proposal and related communication.
In some markets, companies
tend to rely more heavily on direct communication
with relationship managers, who play a
key role in following up on recommendations.
In other markets, such as the Nordics and
the UK, the digital channel is the primary
means both for alerting a customer to a recommended
action and for delivering more
detailed information about the opportunity.</p>
<h2>Consolidate data for analysis in three waves</h2>
<p>The data reserves required to power an NPtB
engine are consolidated in three waves. As
the volume and complexity of data increase
across the three waves, analytical algorithms
become progressively more sophisticated and
accurate in predicting precise, time-critical
needs of individual customers.</p>
<p>The first wave starts with the aggregation and
analysis of internal structured data of various
formats, including customer demographics,
product usage, profitability, and transaction
history. For example, one bank in Europe
started by consolidating the information it
had for 1.3 million SME customers, ranging
from beauty salons, doctors offices, and
family-owned stores to small manufacturing
companies and technology start-ups. This
data set yielded 1,200 variables for analysis.</p>
<p>Continuing the focus on internal data, the
second wave introduces algorithms capable
of digesting unstructured data (e.g., call records,
email communication), as well as a
broader range of structured data from CRM
systems (e.g., share of wallet, historical risk
scoring, maturities, customer relationship
lifecycle, company value chain, and suppliers).
Fast-evolving algorithms augment the
value of data already at hand by learning to
recognize unanticipated clusters and associations
in increasingly complex data sets. The
algorithms generate actionable insights into
a companys current needs, from payables
management to financing for new equipment,
based on information coming from transactions
and payments along the customer value
chain.</p>
<p>The third wave analyzes a broad range of data
from point-of-sale transactions to industry
news and comments on social media to generate
ever more precise recommendations. As
machine learning algorithms become more
sophisticated, it is possible to produce recommendations
from increasingly diverse types
of unstructured data (including, voice, image,
and video files) extracted from industry and
company websites, as well as news and social
media (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/using%20data%20to%20unlock%20the%20potential%20of%20an%20sme%20and%20midcorporate%20franchise/svzg-using-data-unlock-potential-sme-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Data from diverse sources are consolidated in successive waves of increasing complexity." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/using%20data%20to%20unlock%20the%20potential%20of%20an%20sme%20and%20midcorporate%20franchise/svzg-using-data-unlock-potential-sme-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h2>How to build an NPtB engine: Design, develop, deploy</h2>
<p>The preparation of an NPtB model moves
through three phases: design, development,
and deployment. Clear milestones mark the advance from analytics to proof-of-concept to
implementation in the front line.</p>
<h3>Design the NPtB engine</h3>
<p>This first phase is the preparation and design
of the NPtB engineadjusting the scope,
mapping pitfalls, and elaborating the business
case to convince stakeholders throughout
the organization of the value of the effort.
This phase has five key activities:</p>
<ol>
    <li><em>Prepare the data.</em> Looking across the three
    waves of data consolidation, the first step
    is to <a href="/capabilities/quantumblack/our-insights/achieving-business-impact-with-data">identify the types and sources of data</a>
    and map the variables that can be analyzed.
    The goal is to locate data that can be combined
    with unique customer identifiers
    and provide sufficient record history (at
    least two years of data). It is also necessary
    during this phase to check data quality
    (that is, data consistency, format validation)
    to identify points for improvement
    and to restructure data ingestion (for example,
    defining treatment of unavailable
    values and primary keys, synchronizing
    time periods).</li>
    <li><em>Ensure the IT infrastructure meets the
    processing requirements to run the
    model.</em> It is important to design the recommendation
    engine so that it runs efficiently
    on the current IT infrastructure. Most
    banks have adequate processing and storage
    capacity to run basic NBA models that
    will generate actionable recommendations.
    For example, a CPU system with expanded
    memory capacity is adequate to run induction
    algorithms based on decision trees.
    However, deep learning algorithms require
    a GPU system to support complex artificial neural networks.</li>
    <li><em>Identify business sponsor and form multidisciplinary
    team.</em> The sponsor should
    be a business-line owner authorized to
    make binding decisions. The team should
    include data scientists, data engineers,
    business translators, UX designers, and
    data architects. The team identifies the
    variables to be analyzed and builds the
    analytical model based on precise understanding
    of business goals, including
    familiarity with the market segment to be
    addressed and the products to be targeted.</li>
    <li><em>Scope the effort and build the business
    case.</em> The executive team must reach a
    shared understanding of the problem to
    be solved and agree on a back of the envelope
    business case for the NPtB effort. It
    should also identify the main elements for
    evaluation (model performance, adoption
    rate, conversion rate improvement, etc.).</li>
    <li><em>Identify potential roadblocks.</em> It is crucial
    to follow proper legal and compliance
    procedures to ensure that the bank has the
    necessary consent/permission to use and
    merge the targeted data. In our experience,
    most of the data available for the corporate
    segment can be leveraged for NPtB analysis;
    however, it is important to identify
    early in the design phase any business limitations
    that may delay implementation.
    Such limitations may include, for example,
    business involvement, change management
    challenges, and workers council policies.
    </li>
</ol>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients">Financial Services Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients/payments" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Visit our Payments page</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h3>Develop the analytical solution</h3>
<p>In the development phase, data scientists,
data engineers, and business translators collaborate
to build the analytical solution of the
NPtB model. The goal is to identify the products
a customer is likely to buy, prioritize
recommendations, and determine the most
effective channels for delivering an offer. The
team works toward these goals by building algorithms
to answer three main questions:</p>
<ol>
    <li><em>Which products does a particular company
    need or is willing to acquire?</em> The
    NPtB analytical engine identifies opportunities
    for cross-selling. For each specific
    company doing business with the bank, the
    engine ranks commercial leads for each
    product according to two criteria: probability
    (which leads are most likely to result
    in a transaction?) and value (which will be
    most profitable?).</li>
    <li><em>Which companies need a particular
    product?</em> Next, the engine also prioritizes
    clients according to their potential value/
    business priorities, propensity to buy, and
    more. (This step is particularly helpful for
    relationship managers, who must decide
    how to prioritize follow-up calls and visits.)</li>
    <li><em>Which channels should be used to optimize
    the success rate of the commercial
    opportunities?</em> Leads are distributed to
    digital and traditional channels based on
    company behavior and preferences, contact
    policies, and relationship managers
    commercial activities.</li>
</ol>
<p>To answer these three questions precisely,
banks can analyze customer data, such as
payments transactions and digital interactions.
Machine learning algorithms can identify
patterns in past customer behavior to
predict future customer purchases. Data scientists
build NPtB engines leveraging modeling
environments such as R, Python, or Spark.</p>
<p>While deep-learning algorithms generate the
most accurate predictions if data sources are complex and unstructured, gradient boosting
machines, random forest algorithms, and even
logistic regressions provide valuable commercial
opportunities for the NPtB engine. In
addition, gradient boosting machines have the
advantage of generating reliable recommendations
with smaller data sets or data sets where
there are gaps. These models are trained with
past data and statistically back-tested on an
out-of-sample and out-of-time customer base
to quantify model performance.</p>
<h3>Deploy and pilot NPtB engine</h3>
<p>The last phase is to embed recommendations
in digital channels and relationship managers
interactions with clients. Banks test and
refine the NPtB pilot in the field before rolling
it out to the full market.</p>
<p>A European bank recently tested an NPtB engine
in five branches to evaluate the precision
of sales leads. A team of relationship managers,
product specialists, and branch managers
participated in the pilot, which included
training on how to follow up on recommendations
and testing the effectiveness of leads
with clients. Over three months, the team
tested the leads with companies and provided feedback. A skeptical relationship manager
selected an offer for a letter of guarantee
recommended for a particular client, and
commented, I dont believe the customer
will buy this, I know the company. When
the relationship manager asked the company
owner if he needed a letter of guarantee this
month, he answered, How did you know? I
am currently negotiating this product with
another bank.</p>
<p>In the course of a similar pilot with another
financial institution, the model predicted
that 4,500 companies, for which there was
no indication in the data of previous international
trade activity, would purchase international
trade products in the coming month. As it happened one in five of these companies
purchased an international trade product for
the first time within 30 days. Based on the
performance of the pilot, the analytics team
updated the model before implementing it
across the entire organization to target more
than one million customers. The full launch
included four weeks of coaching for more
than 600 relationship managers. Within five
months of starting the project, the NPtB was
fully up and running, with the predictive
model stabilized and relationship managers
fully trained. Ultimately, this bank increased
new sales by more than 30 percent, and relationship
managers increased their interactions
with commercial customers by more
than 50 percent.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Smarter analytics for banks" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/smarter%20analytics%20for%20banks/smarter-analytics-for-banks_1536x1536-600offset.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Smarter analytics for banks</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/smarter-analytics-for-banks" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>The pilot is an important opportunity to secure
the endorsement of team members participating
in the pilot, who then share information
about the model with other colleagues. The
pilot is also an opportunity to test metrics for
evaluating the sales process, such as number
of visits, percent of leads used by relationship
managers, conversion rates, and the level of
satisfaction among relationship managers participating
in the pilot (versus control group).
In addition, the pilot phase is the time to begin
testing long-term performance metrics (in
order to ensure sustainability in the front line),
for example, hit rates for branch staff and relationship
managers, customer profitability, and
customer satisfaction.</p>
<p>In the transition from pilot to full roll-out, it
is crucial to ensure that the organization is
aligned around the NPtB use case and that a
support team is assigned for the deployment.</p>
<h2>Adapting an NPtB engine to serve large corporate clients</h2>
<p>Banks have also been able to improve the
relevance and timeliness of their recommendations
to large corporate clients. At
many institutions, relationship managers are
thoroughly familiar with the general needs
of their corporate customers, but sometimes
they are at a loss to anticipate changes in
these needs. This was once the case for a large
European bank operating in diverse regions.
It now draws on a broad range of data to understand
general market trends and specific
company behaviors. This requires not only applying
advanced analytics to traditional types
of information (annual reports, market conditions,
competitor news) but also collecting
publicly available data on social media (company-
managed pages, customer comments,
etc.). An NPtB engine extracts insights from
available data to alert corporate treasurers to
new opportunities, for example, to leverage
complex banking relationships to improve cash
flow and lower the cost of short-term financing.
Identified leads include opportunities in
various currencies, possibly triggering a change
in cross-border pooling arrangements; letters
of credit, domestic and international guarantees; or even investment banking products, e.g.,
debt capital management. NPtB engines can
boost new sales among large corporate clients
by as much as 15 percent.</p>
<h2>Implementing NPtB for SMEs/midcorporates</h2>
<p>The lessons learned from banks that have
implemented an NPtB engine can be summarized
in five points:</p>
<ol>
    <li><em>Design the NPtB engine according to the
    characteristics of the market segments
    served.</em> Consider first internal data, including
    company profiles, relationship
    characteristics, product granularity, and
    opportunities. Expand the data set to include
    external data, testing the relevance
    of the new variables in generating useful
    recommendations. In developing algorithms
    to generate predictions for the large
    corporate segment, it is important to test
    a broad variety of external data in order
    to build a robust data set that can produce
    insights with a new level of accuracy.</li>
    <li><em>Build the model around customer needs
    and interests.</em> One of the biggest impacts
    is shifting from a product push approach
    to interactions that address specific customer
    needs, as reflected in current transaction
    activity and financial performance.
    This shift enables relationship managers,
    service representatives, and product specialists
    to help customers weigh their options
    and choose the path that best serves
    the companys financial interests.</li>
    <li><em>Pilot the outcome of the NPtB engine to
    build confidence and secure buy-in.</em> Relationship
    managers must be confident in
    the opportunities identified by the NPtB
    engine; at the end of the process they will
    leverage leads to improve their sales effectiveness,
    but change management and
    internal buy-in are key for successful implementation.</li>
    <li><em>Focus on prototypes that create excitement.</em>
    Dont let IT and the complexity of
    legacy systems become the bottleneck, but
    start with a pragmatic proof-of-concept
    to demonstrate the models potential.
    Quick test-and-learn prototypes have
    multiple purposes, including learning and
    improving but above all showing prompt
    impact to create enthusiasm.</li>
    <li><em>Ensure impact from multiple levers.</em> Better
    targeting based on analytics is crucial,
    but there are additional levers, including
    the timing of recommendations, framing
    recommendations within a broader value
    proposition, measuring the impact of recommendations
    (including the performance
    of relationship managers), which can also
    improve performance.</li>
</ol>

are meeting the needs of hundreds of thousands of commercial customers, with new levels of convenience and cost efficiency."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2018-10-08T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]] \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBanks have long pondered\u003c/strong\u003e the untapped value of the commercial segment but\noften lack the means to identify the precise needs of individual companies in\nthis large and diverse population. This is changing, however. By mining huge\nreserves of customer data, banking analytics leaders are meeting the needs of\nhundreds of thousands of commercial customers\u0026mdash;from small businesses to\nmedium-size corporations\u0026mdash;with new levels of convenience and cost efficiency.\nSeveral banks have achieved a ten-fold increase in the success rate of product\nrecommendations, thus delivering highly relevant offers with clear economic\nbenefit. This article highlights recent examples of how \u0026ldquo;next-product-to-buy\u0026rdquo;\n(NPtB) recommendation engines are identifying time-critical needs for their\nsmall- and medium-size enterprise (SME) and mid-corporate clients.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe problem: Most businesses are \u0026ldquo;invisible\u0026rdquo;\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMany banks currently use rules-based models\nto generate recommendations for SMEs and\nmid-corporate companies (with annual sales\nup to $100 million), but with limited success.\nRelationship managers often view these recommendations\nwith skepticism, as conversion\nrates typically range between three and\nfive percent. They resort to general propositions\ndesigned for the consumer segment and\ndevote most of their energy to those clients\nwhose businesses they already know well and\nwhose needs they can anticipate reliably. The\nresult is that 25 percent of a bank\u0026rsquo;s commercial\ncustomers usually account for 85 percent\nof the revenues, and the remaining 75 percent\nrepresents the \u0026ldquo;long tail\u0026rdquo; of untapped potential.\nThese companies are effectively invisible\nto the bank\u0026rsquo;s sales force (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003ch2\u003eThe solution: Anticipate the client\u0026rsquo;s next step\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBanks are investing in building up predictive\nmodels globally: US Bank and TD Bank\nin North America; Itau and Banco do Brasil\nin Latin America; Barclays Bank and Lloyds\nBank in the UK; ING, Banco Santander, and\nBBVA in Europe are just some examples of\nbanks improving their commercial performance\nby \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/how-machine-learning-can-improve-pricing-performance\"\u003eleveraging machine learning\u003c/a\u003e. These\nadvanced techniques have proven effective\nin diverse customer segments, from self-employed\nindividuals to large corporate customers.\nSMEs and mid-corps are the sweet-spot\nfor NPtB, as they generate massive amounts\nof data, which are typically underused. With\nthe help of advanced analytics decisioning\nengines, banks have demonstrated that it is\nnow practical to mine vast (and often messy)\namounts of data, separating signal from\nnoise, to arrive at precise recommendations\nfor a client\u0026rsquo;s next action. In addition, by\nbroadening the types of data collected for the\ncommercial segment, banks are also analyzing\ncustomer behaviors, transactions, and\ncustomer preferences across more extensive\ndatabases.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSuccessful implementation of NPtB engines\nhas boosted new sales upwards of 30 percent\nand increased commercial segment revenues\nby between two to three percent. The impact\non sales efficiency has been radical in some cases, with an increase of more than 50 percent\nin the number of leads offered per client and as\nmany as six out of ten customers purchasing a\nnew product in response to a sales call.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eLeveraging data for NPTB recommendations\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[sidebar NBA]]\n\u003cp\u003eMore than a decade ago, Amazon and Netflix\nbegan leveraging data and analytics to\nimprove their cross-selling efforts. They\nstarted with simple analytics, dividing huge\ncustomer populations into several dozens of\nmicrosegments according to key behaviors\n(inputs). In order to achieve this new level of\nprecision, they used singular value decomposition\n(SVD) to classify customers according\nto patterns in their purchase histories, each\npattern culminating in a target output, that\nis, the \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/how-to-make-sure-your-next-product-or-service-launch-drives-growth\"\u003enext product to buy\u003c/a\u003e.\u0026rdquo; The number of\ninputs and the complexity of the algorithms\nused to analyze these inputs have been increasing\nin recent years, achieving outputs\nthat have much greater precision than was\npossible with next-best-action (NBA) models.\n(See sidebar \u0026ldquo;From NBA to NPtB\u0026rdquo; for a summary of the\nevolution of NPtB from NBA.)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe NBA engines employed by Amazon (with\nmore than 300 million customers reported\nin 2016) and Netflix (125 million subscribers\nreported in the first quarter of 2018) are not entirely suited to banks serving SMEs and\nlarge corporations with products/services\nthat address a relatively narrow range of\nbusiness activity\u0026mdash;domestic and cross-border\npayments, financing, documentary credit,\ninvestments, and insurance. By building NBA\nrecommendation engines designed specifically\nfor transaction banking, banks have\nincreased service levels and profitability,\nimproving their responsiveness to SMEs and\nhelping large corporate clients cut through\ncomplex banking relationships and account\nstructures to optimize liquidity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo maximize the impact of each recommendation,\ndecision engines should identify both\ncustomer needs and the preferred channel(s)\nfor delivering the proposal and related communication.\nIn some markets, companies\ntend to rely more heavily on direct communication\nwith relationship managers, who play a\nkey role in following up on recommendations.\nIn other markets, such as the Nordics and\nthe UK, the digital channel is the primary\nmeans both for alerting a customer to a recommended\naction and for delivering more\ndetailed information about the opportunity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eConsolidate data for analysis in three waves\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe data reserves required to power an NPtB\nengine are consolidated in three waves. As\nthe volume and complexity of data increase\nacross the three waves, analytical algorithms\nbecome progressively more sophisticated and\naccurate in predicting precise, time-critical\nneeds of individual customers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe first wave starts with the aggregation and\nanalysis of internal structured data of various\nformats, including customer demographics,\nproduct usage, profitability, and transaction\nhistory. For example, one bank in Europe\nstarted by consolidating the information it\nhad for 1.3 million SME customers, ranging\nfrom beauty salons, doctor\u0026rsquo;s offices, and\nfamily-owned stores to small manufacturing\ncompanies and technology start-ups. This\ndata set yielded 1,200 variables for analysis.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eContinuing the focus on internal data, the\nsecond wave introduces algorithms capable\nof digesting unstructured data (e.g., call records,\nemail communication), as well as a\nbroader range of structured data from CRM\nsystems (e.g., share of wallet, historical risk\nscoring, maturities, customer relationship\nlifecycle, company value chain, and suppliers).\nFast-evolving algorithms augment the\nvalue of data already at hand by learning to\nrecognize unanticipated clusters and associations\nin increasingly complex data sets. The\nalgorithms generate actionable insights into\na company\u0026rsquo;s current needs, from payables\nmanagement to financing for new equipment,\nbased on information coming from transactions\nand payments along the customer value\nchain.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe third wave analyzes a broad range of data\nfrom point-of-sale transactions to industry\nnews and comments on social media to generate\never more precise recommendations. As\nmachine learning algorithms become more\nsophisticated, it is possible to produce recommendations\nfrom increasingly diverse types\nof unstructured data (including, voice, image,\nand video files) extracted from industry and\ncompany websites, as well as news and social\nmedia (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003ch2\u003eHow to build an NPtB engine: Design, develop, deploy\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe preparation of an NPtB model moves\nthrough three phases: design, development,\nand deployment. Clear milestones mark the advance from analytics to proof-of-concept to\nimplementation in the front line.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDesign the NPtB engine\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis first phase is the preparation and design\nof the NPtB engine\u0026mdash;adjusting the scope,\nmapping pitfalls, and elaborating the business\ncase to convince stakeholders throughout\nthe organization of the value of the effort.\nThis phase has five key activities:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePrepare the data.\u003c/em\u003e Looking across the three\n    waves of data consolidation, the first step\n    is to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/quantumblack/our-insights/achieving-business-impact-with-data\"\u003eidentify the types and sources of data\u003c/a\u003e\n    and map the variables that can be analyzed.\n    The goal is to locate data that can be combined\n    with unique customer identifiers\n    and provide sufficient record history (at\n    least two years of data). It is also necessary\n    during this phase to check data quality\n    (that is, data consistency, format validation)\n    to identify points for improvement\n    and to restructure data ingestion (for example,\n    defining treatment of unavailable\n    values and primary keys, synchronizing\n    time periods).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEnsure the IT infrastructure meets the\n    processing requirements to run the\n    model.\u003c/em\u003e It is important to design the recommendation\n    engine so that it runs efficiently\n    on the current IT infrastructure. Most\n    banks have adequate processing and storage\n    capacity to run basic NBA models that\n    will generate actionable recommendations.\n    For example, a CPU system with expanded\n    memory capacity is adequate to run induction\n    algorithms based on decision trees.\n    However, deep learning algorithms require\n    a GPU system to support complex artificial neural networks.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIdentify business sponsor and form multidisciplinary\n    team.\u003c/em\u003e The sponsor should\n    be a business-line owner authorized to\n    make binding decisions. The team should\n    include data scientists, data engineers,\n    business translators, UX designers, and\n    data architects. The team identifies the\n    variables to be analyzed and builds the\n    analytical model based on precise understanding\n    of business goals, including\n    familiarity with the market segment to be\n    addressed and the products to be targeted.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eScope the effort and build the business\n    case.\u003c/em\u003e The executive team must reach a\n    shared understanding of the problem to\n    be solved and agree on a \u0026ldquo;back of the envelope\u0026rdquo;\n    business case for the NPtB effort. It\n    should also identify the main elements for\n    evaluation (model performance, adoption\n    rate, conversion rate improvement, etc.).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIdentify potential roadblocks.\u003c/em\u003e It is crucial\n    to follow proper legal and compliance\n    procedures to ensure that the bank has the\n    necessary consent/permission to use and\n    merge the targeted data. In our experience,\n    most of the data available for the corporate\n    segment can be leveraged for NPtB analysis;\n    however, it is important to identify\n    early in the design phase any business limitations\n    that may delay implementation.\n    Such limitations may include, for example,\n    business involvement, change management\n    challenges, and workers\u0026rsquo; council policies.\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis1]]\n\u003ch3\u003eDevelop the analytical solution\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the development phase, data scientists,\ndata engineers, and business translators collaborate\nto build the analytical solution of the\nNPtB model. The goal is to identify the products\na customer is likely to buy, prioritize\nrecommendations, and determine the most\neffective channels for delivering an offer. The\nteam works toward these goals by building algorithms\nto answer three main questions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhich products does a particular company\n    need or is willing to acquire?\u003c/em\u003e The\n    NPtB analytical engine identifies opportunities\n    for cross-selling. For each specific\n    company doing business with the bank, the\n    engine ranks commercial leads for each\n    product according to two criteria: probability\n    (which leads are most likely to result\n    in a transaction?) and value (which will be\n    most profitable?).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhich companies need a particular\n    product?\u003c/em\u003e Next, the engine also prioritizes\n    clients according to their potential value/\n    business priorities, propensity to buy, and\n    more. (This step is particularly helpful for\n    relationship managers, who must decide\n    how to prioritize follow-up calls and visits.)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhich channels should be used to optimize\n    the success rate of the commercial\n    opportunities?\u003c/em\u003e Leads are distributed to\n    digital and traditional channels based on\n    company behavior and preferences, contact\n    policies, and relationship managers\u0026rsquo;\n    commercial activities.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo answer these three questions precisely,\nbanks can analyze customer data, such as\npayments transactions and digital interactions.\nMachine learning algorithms can identify\npatterns in past customer behavior to\npredict future customer purchases. Data scientists\nbuild NPtB engines leveraging modeling\nenvironments such as R, Python, or Spark.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile deep-learning algorithms generate the\nmost accurate predictions if data sources are complex and unstructured, gradient boosting\nmachines, random forest algorithms, and even\nlogistic regressions provide valuable commercial\nopportunities for the NPtB engine. In\naddition, gradient boosting machines have the\nadvantage of generating reliable recommendations\nwith smaller data sets or data sets where\nthere are gaps. These models are trained with\npast data and statistically back-tested on an\nout-of-sample and out-of-time customer base\nto quantify model performance.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDeploy and pilot NPtB engine\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe last phase is to embed recommendations\nin digital channels and relationship managers\u0026rsquo;\ninteractions with clients. Banks test and\nrefine the NPtB pilot in the field before rolling\nit out to the full market.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA European bank recently tested an NPtB engine\nin five branches to evaluate the precision\nof sales leads. A team of relationship managers,\nproduct specialists, and branch managers\nparticipated in the pilot, which included\ntraining on how to follow up on recommendations\nand testing the effectiveness of leads\nwith clients. Over three months, the team\ntested the leads with companies and provided feedback. A skeptical relationship manager\nselected an offer for a letter of guarantee\nrecommended for a particular client, and\ncommented, \u0026ldquo;I don\u0026rsquo;t believe the customer\nwill buy this, I know the company.\u0026rdquo; When\nthe relationship manager asked the company\nowner if he needed a letter of guarantee this\nmonth, he answered, \u0026ldquo;How did you know? I\nam currently negotiating this product with\nanother bank.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the course of a similar pilot with another\nfinancial institution, the model predicted\nthat 4,500 companies, for which there was\nno indication in the data of previous international\ntrade activity, would purchase international\ntrade products in the coming month. As it happened one in five of these companies\npurchased an international trade product for\nthe first time within 30 days. Based on the\nperformance of the pilot, the analytics team\nupdated the model before implementing it\nacross the entire organization to target more\nthan one million customers. The full launch\nincluded four weeks of coaching for more\nthan 600 relationship managers. Within five\nmonths of starting the project, the NPtB was\nfully up and running, with the predictive\nmodel stabilized and relationship managers\nfully trained. Ultimately, this bank increased\nnew sales by more than 30 percent, and relationship\nmanagers increased their interactions\nwith commercial customers by more\nthan 50 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis2]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe pilot is an important opportunity to secure\nthe endorsement of team members participating\nin the pilot, who then share information\nabout the model with other colleagues. The\npilot is also an opportunity to test metrics for\nevaluating the sales process, such as number\nof visits, percent of leads used by relationship\nmanagers, conversion rates, and the level of\nsatisfaction among relationship managers participating\nin the pilot (versus control group).\nIn addition, the pilot phase is the time to begin\ntesting long-term performance metrics (in\norder to ensure sustainability in the front line),\nfor example, hit rates for branch staff and relationship\nmanagers, customer profitability, and\ncustomer satisfaction.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the transition from pilot to full roll-out, it\nis crucial to ensure that the organization is\naligned around the NPtB use case and that a\nsupport team is assigned for the deployment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eAdapting an NPtB engine to serve large corporate clients\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBanks have also been able to improve the\nrelevance and timeliness of their recommendations\nto large corporate clients. At\nmany institutions, relationship managers are\nthoroughly familiar with the general needs\nof their corporate customers, but sometimes\nthey are at a loss to anticipate changes in\nthese needs. This was once the case for a large\nEuropean bank operating in diverse regions.\nIt now draws on a broad range of data to understand\ngeneral market trends and specific\ncompany behaviors. This requires not only applying\nadvanced analytics to traditional types\nof information (annual reports, market conditions,\ncompetitor news) but also collecting\npublicly available data on social media (company-\nmanaged pages, customer comments,\netc.). An NPtB engine extracts insights from\navailable data to alert corporate treasurers to\nnew opportunities, for example, to leverage\ncomplex banking relationships to improve cash\nflow and lower the cost of short-term financing.\nIdentified leads include opportunities in\nvarious currencies, possibly triggering a change\nin cross-border pooling arrangements; letters\nof credit, domestic and international guarantees; or even investment banking products, e.g.,\ndebt capital management. NPtB engines can\nboost new sales among large corporate clients\nby as much as 15 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eImplementing NPtB for SMEs/midcorporates\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe lessons learned from banks that have\nimplemented an NPtB engine can be summarized\nin five points:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDesign the NPtB engine according to the\n    characteristics of the market segments\n    served.\u003c/em\u003e Consider first internal data, including\n    company profiles, relationship\n    characteristics, product granularity, and\n    opportunities. Expand the data set to include\n    external data, testing the relevance\n    of the new variables in generating useful\n    recommendations. In developing algorithms\n    to generate predictions for the large\n    corporate segment, it is important to test\n    a broad variety of external data in order\n    to build a robust data set that can produce\n    insights with a new level of accuracy.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBuild the model around customer needs\n    and interests.\u003c/em\u003e One of the biggest impacts\n    is shifting from a \u0026ldquo;product push\u0026rdquo; approach\n    to interactions that address specific customer\n    needs, as reflected in current transaction\n    activity and financial performance.\n    This shift enables relationship managers,\n    service representatives, and product specialists\n    to help customers weigh their options\n    and choose the path that best serves\n    the company\u0026rsquo;s financial interests.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePilot the outcome of the NPtB engine to\n    build confidence and secure buy-in.\u003c/em\u003e Relationship\n    managers must be confident in\n    the opportunities identified by the NPtB\n    engine; at the end of the process they will\n    leverage leads to improve their sales effectiveness,\n    but change management and\n    internal buy-in are key for successful implementation.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFocus on prototypes that create excitement.\u003c/em\u003e\n    Don\u0026rsquo;t let IT and the complexity of\n    legacy systems become the bottleneck, but\n    start with a pragmatic \u0026ldquo;proof-of-concept\u0026rdquo;\n    to demonstrate the model\u0026rsquo;s potential.\n    Quick test-and-learn prototypes have\n    multiple purposes, including learning and\n    improving but above all showing prompt\n    impact to create enthusiasm.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEnsure impact from multiple levers.\u003c/em\u003e Better\n    targeting based on analytics is crucial,\n    but there are additional levers, including\n    the timing of recommendations, framing\n    recommendations within a broader value\n    proposition, measuring the impact of recommendations\n    (including the performance\n    of relationship managers), which can also\n    improve performance.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n[[DisruptorSignUp significant advance over those using first- and second-generation\nnext-best-action (NBA) methodologies. In the past decade, product recommendations for corporate transaction\nbanking were generated through statistical analysis of historically observed behaviors across diverse sub-segments\n(usually between 10 and 20 in number). Each recommendation called attention to a particular area (e.g., disbursement\nservices, accounts receivable and working capital management, investments, trade finance, foreign exchange)\nand targeted broadly companies sharing general characteristics, as defined by a limited range of profile data, for example,\ncompany size, geography, industry, supply chain position, financial behaviors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith the proliferation of data points, second-generation NBA recommendation engines required more intensive work\nto describe the data, that is, to teach machines the data features to look for when analyzing a data set. This enabled\nbanks to identify specific products (e.g., receivables financing, FX hedging, corporate procurement cards) that a customer\nwould likely be considering. However, the analysis behind these recommendations focused on behaviors within\nspecific cash-management functions, reinforcing the narrow scope of product \u0026ldquo;silos,\u0026rdquo; with little opportunity to optimize\nfinancial performance across the full value chain.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe goal of feature engineering, therefore, is to find the best combination of variables to enable a learning algorithm\nto recognize meaningful patterns in a particular data set. It is a key process in developing a conventional NBA model\nand until recently was a time-consuming manual process drawing on deep knowledge of business practices.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDrawing upon a much broader set of structured and unstructured data and taking advantage of recent gains in processing\ncapacity, today\u0026rsquo;s NPtB engines generate recommendations that are much more granular and precise than\nis possible with NBA models. The improvement in analytical sophistication and processing power comes thanks to\ndeep learning, which can develop highly accurate predictive algorithms. Neural networks make it possible to automate\nthe discovery of data features and the identification of the best combination of features to produce the targeted\nprediction. These calculations produce remarkably precise predictions and deliver actionable results.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"From NBA to
